T.T1: Tumor 5 cm or less in greatest dimension, no extra-adrenal invasion
T.T2: Tumor greater than 5 cm, no extra-adrenal invasion
T.T3: Tumor of any size with local invasion but not invading adjacent organs
T.T4: Tumor of any size that invades adjacent organs (kidney, pancreas, spleen, etc) or large blood vessels (renal vein or vena cava)

N.NX: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

Stage_Groupings.Stage III: T3, N0, M0 or T1-3, N1, M0
Stage_Groupings.Stage IV: T4, any N, M0 or Any T, Any N, M1

T.T1: Tumor 5 cm or less in greatest dimension, limited to adrenal gland (for adrenal pheochromocytoma) or organ of origin (for paraganglioma)
T.T2: Tumor greater than 5 cm, limited to adrenal or organ of origin
T.T3: Tumor of any size with local invasion (beyond the organ but not to other organs)
T.T4: Tumor of any size that invades nearby organs

N.NX: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

Stage_Groupings.Stage III: T3, N0, M0 or T1-3, N1, M0
Stage_Groupings.Stage IV: T4, Any N, M0 or Any T, Any N, M1

T.T1: Tumor limited to ampulla of Vater or sphincter of Oddi (and/or into duodenal submucosa)​:contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}
T.T2: Tumor invades duodenal muscularis propria
T.T3: Tumor invades pancreas (≤0.5 cm) or extends into peri-pancreatic tissue or duodenal serosa
T.T4: Tumor invades pancreas (>0.5 cm) or involves adjacent organs (beyond pancreas or duodenum)

N.NX: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed
N.N2: Metastasis in 4 or more regional lymph nodes

Stage_Groupings.Stage IIIB: T3, N1, M0 or T1-3, N2, M0
Stage_Groupings.Stage IV: T4, Any N, M0 or Any T, Any N, M1

T.T1: Tumor invades mucosa or submucosa and ≤1 cm
T.T2: Tumor invades muscularis propria or >1 cm in size
T.T3: Tumor invades pancreas or periampullary tissue
T.T4: Tumor invades peripancreatic soft tissue or other adjacent organs

Stage_Groupings.Stage IV: T4, Any N, M0 or Any T, Any N, M1

T.Tis: Carcinoma in situ (anal intraepithelial neoplasia II-III, Bowen disease)
T.T1: Tumor ≤2 cm in greatest dimension
T.T2: Tumor >2 cm but ≤5 cm
T.T3: Tumor >5 cm
T.T4: Tumor of any size invading adjacent organ(s) (such as vagina, urethra, bladder)

N.NX: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed
N.N2: Metastasis in unilateral internal iliac and/or inguinal lymph nodes
N.N3: Metastasis in perirectal and inguinal lymph nodes, or bilateral inguinal and/or internal iliac lymph nodes

Stage_Groupings.Stage IIIB: T3-4, N1, M0 or Any T, N2, M0

T.Tis: Carcinoma in situ (tumor confined to mucosa, including involvement of lamina propria)
T.T1: Tumor invades submucosa (through muscularis mucosae) ≤2 cm
T.T2: Tumor invades muscularis propria or >2 cm (up to 4 cm)
T.T3: Tumor invades subserosa or >4 cm, or with extension to mesoappendix
T.T4: Tumor invades visceral peritoneum (serosa) or directly invades adjacent organs

N.N2: Metastasis in 4 or more regional lymph nodes

M.M1a: Metastasis confined to right lower quadrant (intraperitoneal spread)​:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}
M.M1b: Metastasis to other intraperitoneal sites beyond right lower quadrant
M.M1c: Distant metastasis outside the peritoneal cavity

T.T1: Tumor ≤2 cm
T.T2: Tumor >2 cm but ≤4 cm
T.T3: Tumor >4 cm or extends to ileum
T.T4: Tumor invades adjacent organs or through serosa

Stage_Groupings.Stage IV: T4, Any N, M0 or Any T, Any N, M1

T.T1: Solitary tumor without vascular invasion​:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}
T.T2: Solitary tumor with intrahepatic vascular invasion, OR multiple tumors with or without vascular invasion
T.T3: Tumor perforating the visceral peritoneum (surface of liver) and/or direct invasion of extrahepatic structures
T.T4: Tumor with periductal invasion (for hilar cholangiocarcinoma, may use perihilar staging system)*

T.T1: Tumor confined to the bile duct, with extension up to muscle layer or fibrous tissue
T.T2: Tumor invades beyond the bile duct wall to surrounding adipose or hepatic parenchyma
T.T3: Tumor invades unilateral branches of portal vein or hepatic artery
T.T4: Tumor invades main portal vein or common hepatic artery or invades second-order biliary radicals bilaterally

N.N2: Metastasis to 4 or more regional lymph nodes

T.T1: Tumor confined to the bile duct, ≤5 mm invasion into wall
T.T2: Tumor invades beyond wall >5 mm
T.T3: Tumor invades adjacent structures (pancreas, duodenum) without involvement of celiac axis or SMA
T.T4: Tumor involves celiac axis, SMA (unresectable)

N.N2: Metastasis in 4 or more regional lymph nodes

Stage_Groupings.Stage IV: T4, Any N, M0 or Any T, Any N, M1

T.T1: Tumor invades subepithelial connective tissue (lamina propria)
T.T2: Tumor invades muscularis propria (detrusor muscle)
T.T2a: Tumor invades superficial (inner) half of muscularis propria
T.T2b: Tumor invades deep (outer) half of muscularis propria
T.T3: Tumor invades perivesical tissue (beyond muscularis into fat)
T.T4: Tumor invades any of the following: prostate stroma, uterus, vagina, pelvic wall, or abdominal wall
T.T4a: Tumor invades prostate stroma, uterus, or vagina
T.T4b: Tumor invades pelvic wall or abdominal wall

N.NX: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed
N.N1: Metastasis in a single lymph node ≤2 cm
N.N2: Metastasis in a single node >2 cm to 5 cm, or multiple nodes (all ≤5 cm)
N.N3: Metastasis in a lymph node >5 cm

M.M1a: Metastasis to distant lymph node(s) beyond common iliac nodes

Stage_Groupings.Stage III: T3 or T4a, N0, M0

name: Bone Sarcoma (Appendicular Skeleton, Trunk, Skull, Facial Bones)

T.T1: Tumor ≤8 cm in greatest dimension
T.T2: Tumor >8 cm in greatest dimension
T.T3: Discontinuous tumors in the primary bone site (skip lesions)

Stage_Groupings.Stage IB: T2 or T3, N0, M0, Grade 1-2
Stage_Groupings.Stage III: T3, N0, M0, Grade 3-4

T.T2: Tumor >8 cm
T.T3: Discontinuous tumors in the primary bone site
T.T4: Tumor invades spinal canal or great vessels (applicable to spine/pelvis)

N.NX: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

Stage_Groupings.Stage IB: T2 or T3, N0, M0, Grade 1-2
Stage_Groupings.Stage III: T3, N0, M0, Grade 3-4
Stage_Groupings.Stage IVB: Any T, N1, Any M or Any T, Any N, M1b

T.Tis: Carcinoma in situ (DCIS or LCIS); Paget disease of nipple with no tumor​:contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}
T.T1: Tumor ≤2 cm in greatest dimension​:contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}
T.T2: Tumor >2 cm but ≤5 cm​:contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}
T.T3: Tumor >5 cm​:contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}
T.T4: Tumor of any size with extension to chest wall and/or skin​:contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}
T.T4a: Extension to chest wall (ribs, intercostal, serratus; not just pectoralis muscle)​:contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}
T.T4b: Ulceration or ipsilateral skin nodules or edema (peau d’orange) of skin​:contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}

N.NX: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed
N.cN2: Fixed/matted ipsilateral axillary LN or ipsilateral internal mammary LN without axillary metastasis​:contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}
N.cN3: Ipsilateral infraclavicular LN, or ipsilateral internal mammary + axillary LN, or supraclavicular LN involvement​:contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}
N.pN0: No pathologic lymph node metastasis or only isolated tumor cells (≤0.2 mm)​:contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}
N.pN1mi: Micrometastasis >0.2 mm to 2 mm in lymph node​:contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}
N.pN1a: Metastasis in 1-3 axillary lymph nodes (at least one >2 mm)
N.pN1b: Metastasis in internal mammary nodes detected by sentinel node biopsy (not clinically apparent)​:contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}
N.pN1c: Metastasis in 1-3 axillary nodes and internal mammary nodes detected by SLN​:contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}
N.pN2b: Metastasis in clinically detected internal mammary nodes without axillary metastasis​:contentReference[oaicite:24]{index=24}
N.pN3a: Metastasis in ≥10 axillary lymph nodes, or infraclavicular nodes​:contentReference[oaicite:25]{index=25}
N.pN3b: Metastasis in internal mammary nodes with ≥1 positive axillary node, or >3 axillary nodes with microscopic internal mammary involvement​:contentReference[oaicite:26]{index=26}

M.cM0: No clinical evidence of distant metastasis
M.cM0(i+): No clinical evidence of metastasis, but microscopic tumor cells in blood, bone marrow, etc (≤0.2mm)
M.M1: Distant metastasis (includes metastasis >0.2 mm in distant sites)​:contentReference[oaicite:28]{index=28}

Stage_Groupings.Stage IIA: T0-1, N1, M0 or T2, N0, M0​:contentReference[oaicite:31]{index=31}
Stage_Groupings.Stage IIB: T2, N1, M0 or T3, N0, M0​:contentReference[oaicite:32]{index=32}
Stage_Groupings.Stage IIIA: T0-2, N2, M0 or T3, N1-2, M0​:contentReference[oaicite:33]{index=33}

name: Cervical Lymph Nodes with Unknown Primary (Head & Neck)

N.NX: Regional nodes cannot be assessed
N.N1: Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node ≤3 cm
N.N2: Metastasis in a single ipsilateral 3-6 cm, or multiple ipsilateral ≤6 cm, or bilateral/contralateral ≤6 cm
N.N2c: Metastasis in bilateral or contralateral ≤6 cm
N.N3: Metastasis in a lymph node >6 cm
N.N3a: Metastasis in a lymph node >6 cm
N.N3b: Metastasis with extranodal extension (ENE+) in any node

Stage_Groupings.Stage III: N1, M0 (with no known primary)

T.T1: Tumor confined to cervix uteri (extension to uterine corpus disregarded)
T.T1a: Invasive carcinoma only diagnosed by microscopy (maximum depth ≤5 mm)
T.T1b: Clinically visible lesion or >5 mm depth
T.T2: Tumor invades beyond uterus but not to pelvic wall or lower third of vagina
T.T3: Tumor extends to pelvic wall and/or involves lower third of vagina and/or causes hydronephrosis or non-functioning kidney
T.T3a: Tumor involves lower third of vagina
T.T3b: Tumor extends to pelvic wall and/or causes hydronephrosis
T.T4: Tumor invades mucosa of bladder or rectum, or extends beyond true pelvis

N.NX: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed
N.N2: Metastasis in para-aortic lymph node(s)

M.M1: Distant metastasis (incl. supraclavicular nodes, lung, liver, bone etc.)

Stage_Groupings.Stage III: T3, N0, M0 or Any T, N1, M0
Stage_Groupings.Stage IV: T4, Any N, M0 or Any T, Any N, M1

FIGO_2018.Stage I: Cancer confined to cervix (IA microscopic, IB clinically visible)
FIGO_2018.Stage II: Invades beyond uterus, not to pelvic wall or lower vagina
FIGO_2018.Stage III: Extends to pelvic wall, lower third of vagina, and/or causes hydronephrosis; or involves pelvic/para-aortic LN (IIIC1 pelvic, IIIC2 para-aortic)
FIGO_2018.Stage IV: Spread to adjacent organs (IVA bladder/rectum) or distant organs (IVB)

T.Tis: Carcinoma in situ (intraepithelial or invasion of lamina propria)
T.T1: Tumor invades submucosa
T.T2: Tumor invades muscularis propria
T.T3: Tumor invades through muscularis propria into pericolorectal tissues
T.T4: Tumor invades visceral peritoneum or adjacent organs
T.T4a: Tumor penetrates to surface of visceral peritoneum
T.T4b: Tumor directly invades or is adherent to other organs or structures

N.NX: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed
N.N1c: Tumor deposits in subserosa/mesentery without LN metastasis
N.N2: Metastasis in ≥4 regional lymph nodes
N.N2b: Metastasis in 7 or more regional LNs

M.M1a: Metastasis confined to one organ or site (e.g., liver, lung, ovary, non-regional LN)

Stage_Groupings.Stage IIIA: T1-2, N1, M0 or T1, N2a, M0
Stage_Groupings.Stage IIIB: T3-4a, N1, M0 or T2-3, N2a, M0 or T1-2, N2b, M0
Stage_Groupings.Stage IIIC: T4a, N2a, M0 or T3-4a, N2b, M0 or T4b, N1-2, M0

T.T1: Tumor limited to conjunctiva only
T.T2: Tumor invades cornea, sclera, eyelid, or orbit
T.T3: Tumor invades adjacent structures like orbit extensively or beyond
T.T4: Tumor invades eyeball (globe) or spreads to adjacent sinus or brain

T.T1: Tumor involves conjunctiva only (bulbar, palpebral, or forniceal) and not beyond
T.T2: Tumor invades cornea, sclera, eyelid, or caruncle
T.T3: Tumor invades orbit or sinuses
T.T4: Tumor invades brain or adjacent structures

N.N1: Regional lymph node metastasis (preauricular, submandibular, etc)

T.Tis: Carcinoma in situ (atypical hyperplasia, no longer used clinically)
T.T1: Tumor confined to corpus uteri
T.T1a: Tumor limited to endometrium or invades <50% of myometrium
T.T2: Tumor invades stromal connective tissue of the cervix but not beyond uterus
T.T3: Local and/or regional spread of tumor
T.T3a: Tumor invades serosa of corpus uteri and/or adnexa
T.T4: Tumor invades bladder mucosa and/or bowel mucosa

N.N0(i+): Isolated tumor cells in regional lymph node(s) no greater than 0.2 mm
N.N2: Metastasis to para-aortic lymph nodes

M.M1: Distant metastasis (including inguinal nodes, intraperitoneal disease outside pelvis)

FIGO.Stage I: Tumor confined to corpus uteri (IA invades < half myometrium, IB ≥ half)
FIGO.Stage II: Tumor invades cervical stroma, but confined to uterus
FIGO.Stage III: Local/regional spread (IIIA serosa/adnexa, IIIB vagina/parametria, IIIC nodal spread)
FIGO.Stage IV: Tumor invades bladder/rectum mucosa (IVA) or distant metastasis (IVB)

T.T1: Tumor limited to uterus
T.T2: Tumor extends beyond uterus, within pelvis
T.T3: Tumor invades abdominal tissues (one site)
T.T3b: More than one site of abdominal involvement
T.T4: Tumor invades bladder or rectum

Stage_Groupings.Stage IV: T4 or Any T, Any N, M1

FIGO.Stage I: Tumor limited to uterus (IA ≤5 cm, IB >5 cm)
FIGO.Stage II: Tumor extends to pelvis (IIA adnexa, IIB other pelvic tissue)
FIGO.Stage III: Tumor invades abdominal tissues (IIIA one site, IIIB >1 site, IIIC pelvic/para-aortic nodes)
FIGO.Stage IV: Tumor invades bladder/rectum (IVA) or distant metastasis (IVB)

name: Cutaneous Squamous Cell Carcinoma (Head & Neck region)

T.T1: Tumor ≤2 cm with less than 2 high-risk features
T.T2: Tumor >2 cm or any size with ≥2 high-risk features
T.T3: Tumor invades maxilla, mandible, orbit or temporal bone
T.T4: Tumor invades skull base or spine, or encases carotid artery

N.NX: Regional nodes cannot be assessed
N.N1: Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node ≤3 cm
N.N2a: Metastasis in single ipsilateral node 3-6 cm
N.N2b: Metastases in multiple ipsilateral nodes ≤6 cm

T.T1: Tumor invades lamina propria or submucosa and ≤1 cm
T.T2: Tumor invades muscularis propria or >1 cm
T.T3: Tumor invades through muscularis propria into subserosa or mesentery
T.T4: Tumor invades peritoneum or other organs

Stage_Groupings.Stage IV: T4, Any N, M0 or Any T, Any N, M1

T.Tis: High-grade dysplasia (tumor in situ confined to epithelium)
T.T1: Tumor invades lamina propria, muscularis mucosae or submucosa
T.T1a: Tumor invades lamina propria or muscularis mucosae
T.T2: Tumor invades muscularis propria
T.T3: Tumor invades adventitia
T.T4: Tumor invades adjacent structures
T.T4a: Resectable tumor invading pleura, pericardium, or diaphragm
T.T4b: Unresectable tumor invading aorta, vertebra, or trachea

N.N2: Metastasis in 3-6 regional lymph nodes
N.N3: Metastasis in 7 or more regional lymph nodes

Stage_Groupings.Stage I: T1, N0, M0 (high grade T1 might be IB if T1b etc)
Stage_Groupings.Stage II: T2-3 or N1 in certain combos M0
Stage_Groupings.Stage III: T3 N1 or T4/N2 etc, M0

T.Tis: Carcinoma in situ (including Paget disease in situ)
T.T1: Tumor ≤5 mm in greatest dimension, limited to eyelid
T.T2: Tumor >5 mm and ≤10 mm, limited to eyelid
T.T3: Tumor >10 mm, or any tumor that invades adjacent ocular/adnexal structures (orbit, lacrimal, etc)
T.T4: Tumor invades orbital apex, bone, sinuses, or brain

FIGO (Ovary/FT/Primary Peritoneal).Stage I: Tumor confined to ovaries or fallopian tubes
FIGO (Ovary/FT/Primary Peritoneal).Stage II: Tumor involves one or both ovaries/tubes with pelvic extension
FIGO (Ovary/FT/Primary Peritoneal).Stage III: Tumor spread to peritoneum outside pelvis and/or regional lymph nodes
FIGO (Ovary/FT/Primary Peritoneal).Stage IV: Distant metastasis (pleural effusion with positive cytology or parenchymal metastases)

T.T1: Tumor invades lamina propria or muscularis (a: LP, b: muscle layer)
T.T2: Tumor invades perimuscular connective tissue (no extension beyond serosa)
T.T3: Tumor perforates serosa (visceral peritoneum) and/or directly invades one adjacent organ (liver, stomach, duodenum, colon, pancreas, omentum)
T.T4: Tumor invades main portal vein or hepatic artery or multiple organs

N.N2: Metastasis to ≥4 regional lymph nodes

T.T1: Tumor ≤2 cm
T.T2: Tumor >2 cm ≤5 cm
T.T3: Tumor >5 cm ≤10 cm
T.T4: Tumor >10 cm

N.N0: No regional lymph node metastasis (GISTs rarely spread to nodes)

Additional_Staging_Systems.RiskClassification: Risk of recurrence for GIST also depends on mitotic rate and tumor location, not just TNM.

T.T1: Tumor confined to uterus
T.T2: Tumor extends to adnexa or vagina
T.T3: Tumor extends to lungs
T.T4: Tumor extends to other distant sites

N.N1: Metastasis to genital structures (ovary, tube, vagina)

Stage_Groupings.Stage II: GTN extends to other genital structures
Stage_Groupings.Stage III: GTN extends to lungs (with or without genital involvement)

Additional_Staging_Systems.FIGO_Scoring: Prognostic scoring (0-4 for factors like age, hCG, etc) is used to classify GTN as low-risk or high-risk.

T.T1: Tumor ≤7 cm, limited to kidney
T.T1b: Tumor >4 cm but ≤7 cm, limited to kidney
T.T2: Tumor >7 cm, limited to kidney
T.T2a: Tumor >7 cm but ≤10 cm, limited to kidney
T.T3: Tumor extends into major veins or perinephric tissues, not beyond Gerota's fascia
T.T3a: Tumor invades renal vein or perirenal fat
T.T3b: Tumor extends into vena cava below diaphragm
T.T3c: Tumor extends into vena cava above diaphragm or invades wall of vena cava
T.T4: Tumor invades beyond Gerota's fascia (including adrenal gland)

Stage_Groupings.Stage III: T3, N0, M0 or Any T, N1, M0
Stage_Groupings.Stage IV: T4, Any N, M0 or Any T, Any N, M1

T.T1: Tumor ≤2 cm in greatest dimension, no bone invasion
T.T2: Tumor 2-4 cm or minimal bone invasion
T.T3: Tumor >4 cm or bone invasion beyond lacrimal gland fossa
T.T4: Tumor invades globe, extends beyond orbit, or involves brain

T.T1: Tumor limited to one subsite of larynx with normal vocal cord mobility (glottic: one cord; supraglottic: one area; subglottic: limited to subglottis)
T.T2: Tumor invades adjacent laryngeal subsite or impairs vocal cord mobility
T.T3: Tumor limited to larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades postcricoid, pre-epiglottic space, inner cortex of thyroid cartilage
T.T4: Tumor invades through thyroid cartilage or other adjacent structures
T.T4a: Tumor invades thyroid cartilage, trachea, soft tissues of neck, etc (moderately advanced)
T.T4b: Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases carotid, or mediastinum (very advanced)

N.NX: Regional nodes cannot be assessed
N.N1: Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node ≤3 cm
N.N2: Metastasis in a single ipsilateral 3-6 cm, or multiple ipsilateral ≤6 cm, or bilateral/contralateral ≤6 cm
N.N2c: Metastasis in bilateral or contralateral ≤6 cm
N.N3: Metastasis in a lymph node >6 cm
N.N3a: Metastasis in a lymph node >6 cm

Stage_Groupings.Stage III: T3, N0, M0 or T1-3, N1, M0

Additional_Staging_Systems.Acute_Leukemia: No formal staging; risk stratification based on cytogenetics and response
Additional_Staging_Systems.Chronic_Lymphocytic_Leukemia: Rai Stage 0-IV (lymphocytosis only to organ involvement) and Binet Stage A-C based on node groups​:contentReference[oaicite:34]{index=34}
Additional_Staging_Systems.Chronic_Myelogenous_Leukemia: Phases: Chronic, Accelerated, Blast phase (based on blood counts and blasts percentage)

T.T1: Solitary tumor ≤2 cm, without vascular invasion
T.T2: Solitary tumor >2 cm without vascular invasion, OR multiple tumors none >5 cm, OR solitary tumor ≤2 cm with vascular invasion
T.T3: Multiple tumors with at least one >5 cm
T.T4: Tumor(s) with direct invasion of adjacent organs (except gallbladder) or perforation of visceral peritoneum

name: Lung Carcinoma (Non-Small Cell and Small Cell)

T.TX: Tumor cannot be assessed (e.g., positive sputum cytology, no lesion on imaging)
T.Tis: Carcinoma in situ (including adenocarcinoma in situ)
T.T1mi: Minimally invasive adenocarcinoma (≤3 cm lesion with ≤5 mm invasion)​:contentReference[oaicite:35]{index=35}​:contentReference[oaicite:36]{index=36}
T.T2: Tumor >3 cm but ≤5 cm, or involves main bronchus, or invades visceral pleura, or causes atelectasis extending to hilum​:contentReference[oaicite:40]{index=40}
T.T3: Tumor >5 cm but ≤7 cm; or invades chest wall, phrenic nerve, parietal pericardium; or separate tumor nodule(s) in same lobe​:contentReference[oaicite:43]{index=43}
T.T4: Tumor >7 cm; or invades mediastinum, heart, great vessels, trachea, recurrent laryngeal nerve, esophagus, vertebral body, carina; or separate tumor nodule(s) in different ipsilateral lobe​:contentReference[oaicite:44]{index=44}

N.NX: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed
N.N1: Metastasis in ipsilateral peribronchial and/or ipsilateral hilar lymph nodes and intrapulmonary nodes​:contentReference[oaicite:45]{index=45}
N.N2: Metastasis in ipsilateral mediastinal and/or subcarinal lymph node(s)
N.N3: Metastasis in contralateral mediastinal, contralateral hilar, ipsilateral or contralateral supraclavicular lymph node(s)

M.M1a: Separate tumor nodule(s) in contralateral lobe; or malignant pleural/pericardial effusion or pleural nodules
M.M1c: Multiple extrathoracic metastases or multiple organs

Stage_Groupings.Stage II: T2b-T3, N0, M0 or T1-2, N1, M0

Additional_Staging_Systems.Small_Cell_Lung_Cancer: Traditionally classified as Limited (confined to one hemithorax and regional nodes) or Extensive (beyond one hemithorax)​:contentReference[oaicite:46]{index=46}; can also be staged by TNM.

Stage_Groupings.Stage I: Involvement of a single lymph node region (I) or a single extralymphatic organ or site (IE)
Stage_Groupings.Stage II: Involvement of ≥2 lymph node regions on the same side of diaphragm (II) or with limited contiguous extralymphatic involvement (IIE)
Stage_Groupings.Stage III: Involvement of lymph node regions on both sides of diaphragm (III), which may include spleen (IIIS) or limited contiguous extralymphatic site (IIIE, IIIS/E)
Stage_Groupings.Stage IV: Disseminated involvement of one or more extralymphatic organs (e.g., liver, bone marrow) ± lymph nodes

Additional_Staging_Systems.Ann_Arbor: Stages I-IV as above with suffixes A (no B symptoms) or B (fever, night sweats, weight loss), and other modifiers: E (extralymphatic contiguous), S (splenic), X (bulky disease)​:contentReference[oaicite:47]{index=47}

Stage_Groupings.Stage I: Involvement of a single lymph node region (I) or a single extralymphatic organ or site (IE)
Stage_Groupings.Stage II: Involvement of ≥2 lymph node regions on the same side of diaphragm (II) or with limited contiguous extralymphatic involvement (IIE)
Stage_Groupings.Stage III: Involvement of lymph node regions on both sides of diaphragm (III), which may include spleen (IIIS) or limited contiguous extralymphatic site (IIIE, IIIS/E)
Stage_Groupings.Stage IV: Disseminated involvement of one or more extralymphatic organs (e.g., liver, bone marrow) ± lymph nodes

Additional_Staging_Systems.Ann_Arbor: NHL uses same Ann Arbor I-IV staging​:contentReference[oaicite:48]{index=48} with A/B, E, S, X modifiers. Certain NHL have specialized prognostic indices.

T.T1: Limited patches/plaques covering <10% of skin surface
T.T2: Patches/plaques covering ≥10% of skin surface
T.T3: One or more tumors ≥1 cm
T.T4: Confluence of redness (erythroderma) covering ≥80% body surface

N.N0: No clinically abnormal peripheral lymph nodes
N.N1: Clinically abnormal lymph nodes, histology N1 (dermatopathic only)
N.N2: Clinically abnormal lymph nodes, histology N2 (early involvement)
N.N3: Clinically abnormal lymph nodes, histology N3 (Frank lymphoma)
N.N4: Peripheral blood involvement (Sézary cells present in blood)

T.TX: Primary tumor thickness cannot be assessed
T.T1: Melanoma ≤1.0 mm thickness
T.T2: Melanoma >1.0 to 2.0 mm thickness
T.T3: Melanoma >2.0 to 4.0 mm
T.T4: Melanoma >4.0 mm

N.NX: Regional nodes cannot be assessed
N.N0: No regional lymph node metastasis or in-transit mets
N.N1: Metastasis in 1 regional lymph node or 1 in-transit or satellite metastasis
N.N1c: No nodal metastasis, but one in-transit/satellite metastasis
N.N2: Metastases in 2-3 regional nodes or in-transit/satellite with 1 node
N.N2c: One in-transit/satellite metastasis with regional node metastasis
N.N3: Metastases in ≥4 nodes, or matted nodes, or in-transit/satellite with ≥2 nodes

M.M1a: Distant skin, subcutaneous or nodal metastasis, normal LDH
M.M1c: Metastasis to visceral sites (excluding CNS) and/or elevated LDH

Stage_Groupings.Stage III: Any T, N1-3, M0

T.T3: Mucosal melanoma confined to site of origin
T.T4a: Moderately advanced: tumor invades deep soft tissue, cartilage, bone, or overlying skin
T.T4b: Very advanced: tumor invades brain, dura, skull base, lower cranial nerves, or carotid artery

N.NX: Regional nodes cannot be assessed
N.N1: Metastasis in regional lymph node(s) (any size)

T.T0: No evidence of primary tumor (e.g., nodal Merkel cell carcinoma)
T.T1: Tumor ≤2 cm
T.T2: Tumor >2 cm but ≤5 cm
T.T3: Tumor >5 cm
T.T4: Tumor invades fascia, muscle, cartilage, or bone

N.NX: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed
N.N1a: Micrometastasis (detected by SLN biopsy or microscopic)
N.N2: In-transit metastasis (without lymph node involvement)

M.M1a: Metastasis to skin, subcutaneous or distant lymph nodes

Stage_Groupings.Stage III: Any T, N1-2, M0

T.T1: Tumor involves ipsilateral parietal pleura (± visceral, mediastinal, diaphragmatic pleura) without mediastinal or diaphragmatic invasion
T.T2: Tumor involves ipsilateral pleura with at least one of: diaphragmatic muscle invasion or lung parenchyma invasion
T.T3: Locally advanced but potentially resectable tumor: involves endothoracic fascia, or mediastinal fat, or single focus chest wall soft tissue, or non-transmural pericardium
T.T4: Locally advanced unresectable tumor: diffuse chest wall invasion or through diaphragm or mediastinal organs or spine, or through pleura to contralateral pleura, or peritoneum, or multiple chest wall foci

N.N1: Metastasis in ipsilateral bronchopulmonary or hilar lymph nodes
N.N2: Metastasis in subcarinal or ipsilateral mediastinal lymph nodes
N.N3: Metastasis in contralateral mediastinal, contralateral hilar, or supraclavicular lymph nodes

Stage_Groupings.Stage III: T3 or N2, M0

Additional_Staging_Systems.Durie-Salmon: Stage I (low tumor burden), II (intermediate), III (high), based on hemoglobin, calcium, bone lesions and M-component
Additional_Staging_Systems.ISS: International Staging System I-III based on beta-2 microglobulin and albumin levels
Additional_Staging_Systems.RISS: Revised ISS incorporating chromosomal abnormalities and LDH

T.T1: Tumor restricted to one subsite of nasal cavity or sinus with or without bone invasion
T.T2: Tumor invades two subsites in single region or extends to adjacent region within nasoethmoidal complex, with or without bone invasion
T.T3: Tumor extends to invade the orbit or maxillary sinus or palate or cribriform plate
T.T4: Tumor invades orbital apex, brain, cranial nerves, frontal sinus, skin, or multiple extranasal sites
T.T4a: Moderately advanced (invades orbit, skin of nose/cheek, minimal cranial fossa, pterygoid plates, sphenoid/frontal sinuses)
T.T4b: Very advanced (invades brain, dura, cranial nerves, etc.)

N.NX: Regional nodes cannot be assessed
N.N1: Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node ≤3 cm
N.N2: Metastasis in a single ipsilateral 3-6 cm, or multiple ipsilateral ≤6 cm, or bilateral/contralateral ≤6 cm
N.N2c: Metastasis in bilateral or contralateral ≤6 cm
N.N3: Metastasis in a lymph node >6 cm
N.N3a: Metastasis in a lymph node >6 cm

T.T2: Tumor ≤2 cm and DOI >5 mm but ≤10 mm; or tumor >2 cm but ≤4 cm and DOI ≤10 mm
T.T3: Tumor >4 cm or any tumor with DOI >10 mm

T.T4b: Very advanced: tumor invades masticator space, pterygoid plates, or skull base, or encases carotid artery​:contentReference[oaicite:51]{index=51}

N.N2: Metastasis in a single ipsilateral 3-6 cm, or multiple ipsilateral ≤6 cm, or bilateral/contralateral ≤6 cm
N.N2c: Metastasis in bilateral or contralateral ≤6 cm

N.N3a: Metastasis in a lymph node >6 cm

Stage_Groupings.Stage III: T3, N0, M0 or T1-3, N1, M0

T.T1: Tumor ≤2 cm in greatest dimension, confined to orbit
T.T2: Tumor 2-5 cm, confined to orbit
T.T3: Tumor >5 cm, confined to orbit
T.T4: Tumor invades beyond orbit to adjacent structures

FIGO.Stage I: Tumor confined to ovaries (IA one ovary, IB both ovaries, IC surgical spill or capsule rupture or malignant ascites)​:contentReference[oaicite:52]{index=52}
FIGO.Stage II: Tumor involves one or both ovaries with pelvic extension (IIA uterus/tubes, IIB other pelvic tissues)
FIGO.Stage III: Tumor involves peritoneal implants outside pelvis and/or regional nodes (IIIA microscopic, IIIB macroscopic ≤2cm, IIIC >2cm or nodal metastasis)
FIGO.Stage IV: Distant metastasis beyond peritoneal cavity (IVA pleural effusion positive cytology, IVB parenchymal metastases)

T.Tis: Carcinoma in situ (Pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia III)
T.T1: Tumor ≤2 cm in greatest dimension
T.T2: Tumor >2 cm ≤4 cm
T.T3: Tumor >4 cm

N.N2: Metastasis in ≥4 regional lymph nodes

Stage_Groupings.Stage III: T4, Any N, M0 or Any T, N2, M0

T.T2: Tumor >2 cm ≤4 cm, limited to pancreas

T.T4: Tumor invades adjacent organs or wall of large vessels

Stage_Groupings.Stage III: T3, N0, M0 or Any T, N1, M0
Stage_Groupings.Stage IV: T4, Any N, M0 or Any T, Any N, M1

T.T2: Tumor >2 cm, limited to parathyroid
T.T3: Tumor invades surrounding soft tissue or thyroid
T.T4: Tumor invades adjacent organs (trachea, esophagus) or nerve/vessel

Stage_Groupings.Stage IV: T4, Any N, M0 or Any T, Any N, M1

Additional_Staging_Systems.ALL: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia risk groups (standard vs high risk) based on age, WBC, etc.
Additional_Staging_Systems.Lymphoma: Pediatric Hodgkin/NHL use Ann Arbor or St Jude/Murphy for NHL
Additional_Staging_Systems.Others: Pediatric cancers often have unique staging systems (e.g., neuroblastoma INSS/INRG, Wilms tumor, etc.) separate from TNM.

T.T1: Tumor invades subepithelial connective tissue

T.T1b: With lymphovascular invasion or high grade
T.T2: Tumor invades corpus spongiosum or cavernosum
T.T3: Tumor invades urethra
T.T4: Tumor invades other adjacent structures (scrotum, prostate, etc)

N.N1: Metastasis in a single inguinal lymph node
N.N2: Metastasis in multiple or bilateral inguinal lymph nodes

Stage_Groupings.Stage IV: T4 or N3, M0 or Any T, Any N, M1

T.T4: Tumor intracranial extension and/or involvement of cranial nerves, infratemporal fossa, hypopharynx, orbit, or masticator space

N.N3a: Metastasis in a lymph node >6 cm

T.T1a: Tumor incidental histologic finding in ≤5% of resected tissue
T.T1b: Tumor incidental in >5% of resected tissue

T.T4: Tumor invades adjacent organs or through kidney into perinephric fat

T.T2: Tumor 3.1-6 mm thick or 10.1-16 mm diameter (medium)
T.T3: Tumor 6.1-9 mm thick or 16.1-18 mm diameter (large)
T.T4: Tumor >9 mm thick or >18 mm diameter or extraocular extension

N.N1: Regional lymph node metastasis (if applicable, e.g., conjunctival melanoma separate)

FIGO.Stage II: Tumor invades paravaginal tissue but not pelvic wall
FIGO.Stage III: Tumor extends to pelvic wall and/or causes hydronephrosis or nonfunctioning kidney
FIGO.Stage IVA: Tumor invades bladder or rectal mucosa

FIGO.Stage I: Tumor confined to vulva/perineum (IA ≤2 cm & ≤1 mm invasion; IB >2 cm or >1 mm invasion)
FIGO.Stage II: Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower urethra, lower vagina, anus) and negative nodes
FIGO.Stage III: Tumor of any size with positive inguino-femoral lymph nodes (IIIA 1-2 nodes ≥5mm, IIIB ≥3 nodes ≥5mm or ≥2 <5mm, IIIC extracapsular spread)
FIGO.Stage IVA: Tumor invades upper urethra/vagina, bladder/rectal mucosa, or fixed to pelvic bone, or fixed/ulcerated nodes
